items.title: Data in Key-Value Pairs
items.description: The syntax of JSON is a subset of JavaScript object syntax, with some specific rules:
JSON is made up of key-value pairs. Each key is followed by a colon (:) and the corresponding value.
Keys must be strings, enclosed in double quotes.
Values can be strings, numbers, objects, arrays, booleans (true/false), or null.

items.title: Objects
items.description: Objects in JSON are collections of key-value pairs enclosed in curly braces ({}).
Arrays in JSON are ordered lists of values, enclosed in square brackets ([]).
The values within an array can be of any type, including other objects or arrays.
Numbers: Numbers in JSON can be integers or floats but should not have special formats like dates or functions.
Must be enclosed in double quotes.
Booleans and Null: Represented by the keywords 'true', 'false', and 'null'.
Readability: Its clear format makes it easy to understand, which is advantageous for development and debugging.
Transmission Efficiency: Being a lightweight format, it is ideal for data exchange over networks where bandwidth may be a concern.
Standardization: Its widespread acceptance as a data interchange format ensures that different systems and technologies can interact with each other effectively.
APIs and Web Services: JSON is commonly used in web APIs to send responses from the server to the client. This allows web and mobile applications to process and use the data efficiently.
Project Configuration: Many software projects use JSON for configuration files, like 'package.json' in Node.js projects, which facilitates the management of dependencies and scripts.
